TextEquiv.Unicode: the Corinthians the eight and ninth
Chapters. And to the Galathians,
while wee haverime (saith hee) let us
doe good towardes all men, especial
ly towardes the housholde of faith. In
the first Epistle to Timothie, hee war
neth that there bee consideration had
who should be holpen, and who not to
be holpen. In ye same Epistle he giveth
charege to Timothie, and to al the Bi
shops how to deale with the richer fort
in the Church saying: Commaunde
ehem that are rich in this wotlde, that
they be not high minded, neither put
their trust in uncertaine rithes, but in
the living GOD, who giveth us all
things abundantly to enioy, that they
may doe good, that they may bee rich
in good workes, that they may be rea
die to give and bestow willingly, lay
ing up unto theselves a good fosida
tio against the time to come, that they
may take holde of life everlasting. And
unto the Hebrewes, To do good et to
distribute forget not: for with such sa
crifice God is pleased.
Wherefore, riches were gathered even
in the time of the Apostles to suecour
ye necessity of the poore withal. Deacos
were appointed by the Church as pro
viders and stewardes: among whom
those first Deacons were moste fa
mous, of whom the Actes of the Apo
stles make mention, and also the no
table martyr of Christ Laurence. And
the writings of the ancient fathers do
testifie that with those ecclesiasticall
goods, prisoners were redeemed out of
captivity, poore maides of lawful yeres
manried, finally hospitals, almeries,
spittels, harbours, hostles, and nourse
ries were builded, namely to entertain
pooretravellers, for the maintenaunce
of the poore that were born in that cosi
trie, for the reliefe of the ficke and dis
eased, for the necessitie of old men, and

the Corinthians the eight and ninth Chapters. And to the Galathians, while wee haverime (saith hee) let us doe good towardes all men, especial ly towardes the housholde of faith. In the first Epistle to Timothie, hee war neth that there bee consideration had who should be holpen, and who not to be holpen. In ye same Epistle he giveth charege to Timothie, and to al the Bi shops how to deale with the richer fort in the Church saying: Commaunde ehem that are rich in this wotlde, that they be not high minded, neither put their trust in uncertaine rithes, but in the living GOD, who giveth us all things abundantly to enioy, that they may doe good, that they may bee rich in good workes, that they may be rea die to give and bestow willingly, lay ing up unto theselves a good fosida tio against the time to come, that they may take holde of life everlasting. And unto the Hebrewes, To do good et to distribute forget not: for with such sa crifice God is pleased. Wherefore, riches were gathered even in the time of the Apostles to suecour ye necessity of the poore withal. Deacos were appointed by the Church as pro viders and stewardes: among whom those first Deacons were moste fa mous, of whom the Actes of the Apo stles make mention, and also the no table martyr of Christ Laurence. And the writings of the ancient fathers do testifie that with those ecclesiasticall goods, prisoners were redeemed out of captivity, poore maides of lawful yeres manried, finally hospitals, almeries, spittels, harbours, hostles, and nourse ries were builded, namely to entertain pooretravellers, for the maintenaunce of the poore that were born in that cosi trie, for the reliefe of the ficke and dis eased, for the necessitie of old men, and
for the honest bringing up of puplis &
orphans. Concerning these matters
there are yet ertant certaine imper ial
lawes.
Therefore in reforming of Churs
ches, very diligent heede must be take
that there be no offence committed in
this behalf through oversight or of pur
pose, that the poore be not defrauded, &
that in taking away ons abuse, wee
bring not in many.
If there be plenty of goods, let them
be keptrif there be none, let the be ga
thered of the rich. The let the state of
the poore be searched, and what every
man needeth most, or howe provision
may best be made for every one. which
being knowne, let that which is meete
and necessary for every one bee done
speedily, gently, & diligently. If then
any of the common goods remaine, let
them be kept against such calamities
as may ensue. Let nothing bee consu
med unprofitably or ungodlily,
Again, let not the treasure of the poore
unhappily be detained from them by
fraude, and to the increasing of their
povertie, For there may bee like of
fence commited on both sides. For
on eche side the poor are defrauded of
their goods. Touching liberalitie, wee
have intreated in an other place in
these our Decades : and of providing
for the poore, in other of our woorkes.
And Lewis Vives hath written very
wel of releeving the poore.
The fourth and last part of the
goods of the Church, apperteineth un
to holy buildings, as churches, scholes,
and houses belonging to churches, and
fchooles. Churches which because of
the companies gathered together in :
them are also called cogregations, are
the houses of the Lorde our God. Not
that God whom the wide compasse of
the heavens cannot comprehend, doth

for the honest bringing up of puplis & orphans. Concerning these matters there are yet ertant certaine imper ial lawes. Therefore in reforming of Churs ches, very diligent heede must be take that there be no offence committed in this behalf through oversight or of pur pose, that the poore be not defrauded, & that in taking away ons abuse, wee bring not in many. If there be plenty of goods, let them be keptrif there be none, let the be ga thered of the rich. The let the state of the poore be searched, and what every man needeth most, or howe provision may best be made for every one. which being knowne, let that which is meete and necessary for every one bee done speedily, gently, & diligently. If then any of the common goods remaine, let them be kept against such calamities as may ensue. Let nothing bee consu med unprofitably or ungodlily, Again, let not the treasure of the poore unhappily be detained from them by fraude, and to the increasing of their povertie, For there may bee like of fence commited on both sides. For on eche side the poor are defrauded of their goods. Touching liberalitie, wee have intreated in an other place in these our Decades : and of providing for the poore, in other of our woorkes. And Lewis Vives hath written very wel of releeving the poore. The fourth and last part of the goods of the Church, apperteineth un to holy buildings, as churches, scholes, and houses belonging to churches, and fchooles. Churches which because of the companies gathered together in : them are also called cogregations, are the houses of the Lorde our God.
